translated: Verses of the Elder Nuns .
The Group of Twenties
The Elder Nun Cāpā
In the past I was a hunter,
with a stick in my hand, killing deer.
I was caught in a terrible snare,
but I was unable to get free.
Thinking that I was well-trained,
Cāpā gave birth to a son.
But I cut the bonds of Cāpā,
and I will go forth again.”
“Don’t be angry with me, Great Hero,
don’t be angry with me, Great Sage.
For one overcome with anger
has no purity, let alone spiritual power.”
“I will leave Nāḷā,
but anger will follow me to Nāḷā.
It binds with the form of a woman,
monks who live by the Teaching.”
“Come, Kāḷa, turn back,
and enjoy sensual pleasures as before.
I will be under your control,
as will those who are my relatives.”
“From here to Cāpā is a quarter league,
as you have told me.
For a man who is in love with you,
it would be a great thing.”
“Like a black snake,
like a flower on a mountain top,
like a flowering dālima tree,
like a pāṭali in the middle of the forest.
Your limbs smeared with yellow sandalwood,
wearing the finest Kāsi cloth;
Me, the beautiful one, the peaceful one,

analyzed: kassa ohāya gacchasi  sākuntikā uva sakuṇi  yathā bandhitum icchati
translated: whom will you leave behind and go?”🔽“Just like a bird wants to catch another bird,
you want to bind me with your beauty;
I will not be hindered by you.”
“This son and fruit
that you have produced, Kāḷa;
Me, the one with a son, the peaceful one,
whom will you leave behind and go?”
“The wise abandon their children,
then their relatives, then their wealth;
The great heroes go forth,

original: nāgo chetvāva bandhanaṁ”.🔽“Idāni te imaṁ puttaṁ,
analyzed: nāgo chetvā ava bandhana  idāni te imam putta
translated: like an elephant breaking its bonds.”🔽“Now I will either
beat this son of yours with a stick or a knife,
or I will crush him on the ground,
you will not go out of grief for your son.”
“If you give this son of mine

analyzed: kukkurānam padāhisi  na mam putta katte jammi
translated: to jackals or dogs,🔽you will not bring me back, you murderer,
because of my love for my son.”
“Now then, reverend sir,
where will you go, Kāḷa?
What village, town,
city, or capital?”
“Formerly we were in a group,
not ascetics, but thinking we were ascetics;
We wandered from village to village,
from town to town, from capital to capital.
“This Blessed One, the Buddha,
is on the Nerañjara River;
For the sake of the complete destruction of suffering,🔽he teaches the Dhamma to living beings.

analyzed: dhammam deseti pāṇinā  tassa aham santikam gaccha
translated: I’m going to his presence;
he will be my teacher.”
“Now you should pay homage
to the unsurpassed protector of the world;
After circumambulating him,
you should request the going forth.”
“This is what we should do,
as you say to me.
Now I will pay homage
to the unsurpassed protector of the world;
After circumambulating him,
I will request the going forth.”
Then Kāḷa left
for the Nerañjara River.
He saw the Buddha,

original: desentaṁ amataṁ padaṁ.🔽Dukkhaṁ dukkhasamuppādaṁ,🔽dukkhassa ca atikkamaṁ;
analyzed: a matam  dukkham dukkha samuppāda  dukkhassa ca atikkama
translated: teaching the deathless state.🔽He taught suffering, the origin of suffering,
and the transcending of suffering,🔽and the noble eightfold path
that leads to the stilling of suffering.

analyzed: tassa pādāni vanditvā  katvāna nam padakkhiṇa
translated: After paying homage at his feet,
and circumambulating him,🔽he requested the going forth🔽from Cāpā.
I went forth into homelessness,
Attained the three knowledges,
And accomplished the Buddha’s instruction.
… the nun Cāpā …
